case_vignette: A 50-YEAR-OLD AFRICAN AMERICAN MALE WITH PAST MEDICAL HISTORY OF HYPERTENSION AND HYPERTENSION PRESENTS FOR EVALUATION OF LIGHT SPOTS ON HIS LEGS THAT HE INITIALLY NOTICED ONE YEAR AGO. THE LESIONS ARE NOT PAINFUL OR ITCHY, BUT HE IS CONCERNED THAT THEY ARE INCREASING IN FREQUENCY. WHEN THEY FIRST DEVELOP THEY DO NOT SIGNIFICANTLY GROW IN SIZE. HE HAS NOT TRIED ANY TREATMENTS. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION DEMONSTRATES MULTIPLE HYPOPIGMENTED OVOID MACULES SCATTERED ON THE DISTAL SHINS BILATERALLY.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have light spots on my legs that I first noticed about a year ago.
Have these spots changed in size or appearance since you first noticed them?
No, when they first develop they do not significantly grow in size.
Do the spots itch or cause any other discomfort?
No, the spots are not painful or itchy.
Do you have any medical conditions or are you currently taking any medications?
I have a past medical history of hypertension.
Is there any family history of skin diseases or other autoimmune disorders?
I don't have any information about a family history of skin diseases or autoimmune disorders.
Have you noticed these light spots develop after sun exposure or do they seem unaffected by it?
I don't have any specific information about whether the spots develop after sun exposure or if they are unaffected by it.
Do the spots appear scaly or have a different texture compared to the surrounding skin?
No, the spots do not appear scaly or have a different texture compared to the surrounding skin.
Final Diagnosis: Idiopathic Guttate Hypomelanosis
